member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Control.Connected

summary.para: Returns or sets whether the control is currently connected to the Double Agent server.
The Double Agent control will work whether or not it's connected to the server, but there are are special considerations in each case. See...

member.param: A boolean value specifying whether the control is connected.

remarks.para: You can manually open or close the connection to the server by changing the Connected property. When the connection status changes, any characters you've loaded are automatically unloaded. If you still have references to any objects except the control itself, any attempt to access the objects' properties or methods will fail.

details.para: In many situations, using the control automatically creates a connection with the Double Agent server (depending on the property setting). For example, using the Double Agent control's CLSID in the <OBJECT> tag in a Web page automatically opens a server connection and exiting the page closes the connection. Similarly, for Visual Basic or other languages that enable you to drop a control on a form, running the program automatically opens a connection and exiting the program closes the connection. If the server isn't currently running, it automatically starts.

When you release all references to Agent objects, such as and , the connection with the Double Agent server will automatically be closed. You must also release your reference to the object itself. In Visual Basic, you can release a reference to an object by setting its variable to Nothing. If you have loaded characters, your should unload them before releasing the character object.
details.code:
Dim WithEvents MyAgent as DoubleAgentCtl Dim Genie as DaCtlCharacter
Sub Form_Load ' Create an instance of the control using New Set MyAgent = New DoubleAgentCtl
' Open a connection to the server MyAgent.Connected = True
' Load the character into the Characters collection MyAgent.Characters.Load "Genie", "Genie.acs"
' Create a reference to the character Set Genie = MyAgent.Characters ("Genie") End Sub
Sub CloseConnection ' Unload the character MyAgent.Charcters.Unload "Genie"
' Release the reference to the character object Set Genie = Nothing
' Release the reference to the Agent control Set MyAgent = Nothing End Sub

summary.para: Returns or sets whether an error condition is raised (an exception thrown) for failed requests.

remarks.para: When a method that returns a object fails, there are two ways to detect the error. If RaiseRequestErrors is set, the Double Agent control will raise an error condition. If it's not set, you can check the object's property. An example of a request error is when you specify an animation name that doesn't exist for the method.

member.name: E:DoubleAgent.Control.Control.ActivateInput

summary.para: Signalled when a client becomes input-active.

member.param: The unique identifier of the character that has become input-active.

remarks.para: The input-active client receives mouse and speech input events for the character. Double Agent sends this event only to the client that becomes input-active.

This event can occur when the user uses your object, for example, by choosing a object entry in the or in the pop-up menu for a character. It can also occur when the user selects a character (by clicking or speaking its name), when a character becomes visible, or when the character of another client application becomes hidden.

You can also call the method (with State set to 2) to explicitly make the character topmost, which results in your client application becoming input-active and triggers this event. However, this event does not occur if you use the method only to specify whether or not your client is the active client of the character.

member.name: E:DoubleAgent.Control.Control.ActiveClientChange

summary.para: Signalled when the active client of the character changes.

vbnet.para: Event control_ActiveClientChange (ByVal CharacterID As String, ByVal Active As Boolean)

vb6.para: Sub control_ActiveClientChange (ByVal CharacterID As String, ByVal Active As Boolean)

member.param: The unique identifier of the character that has become active or inactive.
True if the character has become the active client or false if it's no longer the active client.

remarks.para: When multiple clients ( instances) share the same character, the active client of the character receives mouse input (for example, click or drag events). Similarly, when multiple characters are displayed, the active client of the topmost character (also known as the input-active client) receives events.

A client application may receive this event when the user selects one of the client's entries in the character's pop-up menu or by voice command, when the client application changes its active status, or when another client terminates.
Double Agent sends this event only to the clients that are directly affected; that either become the active client or stop being the active client.

member.name: E:DoubleAgent.Control.Control.Click

summary.para: Signalled when the user clicks a character, or the character's icon.

cpp.para: void control_Click (LPCTSTR CharacterID, short Button, short Shift, short X, short Y)

csharp.para: delegate void control_ClickEventHandler (string CharacterID, short Button, short Shift, short X, short Y)

vbnet.para: Event control_Click (ByVal CharacterID As String, ByVal Button As Short, ByVal Shift As Short, ByVal X As Short, ByVal Y As Short)

vb6.para: Sub control_Click (ByVal CharacterID As String, ByVal Button As Integer, ByVal Shift As Integer, ByVal X As Integer, ByVal Y As Integer)

vbscript.para: Sub control_Click (ByVal CharacterID, ByVal Button, ByVal Shift, ByVal X, ByVal Y)

member.param: The unique identifier of the character that was clicked.

remarks.para: This event is sent only to the input-active client of a character. When the user clicks a character or its taskbar icon with no input-active client, Double Agent sends the event to its active client. If the character is visible ( is true), the user's action also sets the character's current input-active client as the last input-active client, sending the event to that client, and then sending the Click event. If the character is hidden ( is false), and the user clicks the character's taskbar icon using button 1, the character is also automatically shown.
remarks.note: Clicking a character does not disable all other character output. However, pressing the Listening key does flush the input-active character's output and triggers the event, passing a that indicates that the client's queue was interrupted.

member.name: E:DoubleAgent.Control.Control.ListenComplete

summary.para: Signalled when Listening mode (speech recognition) has ended.

csharp.para: delegate void control_ListenCompleteEventHandler (string CharacterID, DoubleAgent.Control.ListenCompleteType Cause)

vbnet.para: Event control_ListenComplete (ByVal CharacterID As String, ByVal Cause As DoubleAgent.Control.ListenCompleteType)

vb6.para: Sub control_ListenComplete (ByVal CharacterID As String, ByVal Cause As ListenCompleteType)

member.param: The unique identifier of the listening character.

The cause of the ListenComplete event.
1 Listening mode was turned off by program code.
2 Listening mode (turned on by program code) timed out.
3
Listening mode (turned on by the Listening key) timed out.
4
Listening mode was turned off because the user released the Listening key.
5 Listening mode ended because the user finished speaking.
6 Listening mode ended because the input-active client was deactivated.
7 Listening mode ended because the default character was changed.
8 Listening mode ended because the user disabled speech input.

remarks.para: This event is sent to all clients when the Listening mode time-out ends, after the user releases the Listening key, when the input-active client calls the method with False, or the user has finished speaking. You can use this event to determine when to resume spoken output.

If you turn on Listening mode using the method and then the user presses the Listening key, the Listening mode resets and continues until the Listening key time-out completes, the Listening key is released, or the user finishes speaking, whichever is later. In this situation, you will not receive a ListenComplete event until the Listening key's mode completes.
The event returns the CharacterID to the clients that currently have this character loaded. All other clients receive a null CharacterID (empty string).

member.name: E:DoubleAgent.Control.Control.ListenStart

summary.para: Signalled when Listening mode (speech recognition) begins.

member.param: The unique identifier of the listening character.

remarks.para: This event is sent to all clients when Listening mode begins because the user pressed the Listening key or the input-active client called the method with True. You can use this event to avoid having your character speak while Listening mode is active.

If you turn on Listening mode with the method and then the user presses the Listening key, the Listening mode resets and continues until the Listening key time-out completes, the Listening key is released, or the user finishes speaking, whichever is later. In this situation, when Listening mode is already on, you will not get an additional ListenStart event when the user presses the Listening key.
The event returns the CharacterID to the clients that currently have this character loaded. All other clients receive a null CharacterID (empty string).

member.name: E:DoubleAgent.Control.Control.RequestComplete

summary.para: Signalled when Double Agent completes a queued request.

member.param:
The
object that identifies the completed request.

remarks.para: This event provides a object. Because requests are processed asynchronously, you can use this event to determine when Double Agent finishes processing a request (such as a , , or method) to synchronize this event with other actions generated by your application. Double Agent sends the event only to the client that created the reference to the object, and only if you defined a global variable for the request reference.

example.code:
Dim MyRequest Dim Genie
Sub window_Onload AgentControl.Characters.Load "Genie","Genie.acs"
Set Genie = Agent.Characters("Genie")
' This syntax will generate RequestStart and RequestComplete events. Set MyRequest = Genie.Show(False) ' This syntax will not generate RequestStart and RequestComplete events. Genie.Hide False End Sub
Sub AgentControl_RequestComplete(ByVal Request) If Request Is MyRequest Then Status = "Genie was shown" End Sub

remarks.para: Because animation objects don't get assigned until Double Agent has queued the request, make sure that the object exists before you attempt to evaluate it. For example, in Visual Basic, if you use a conditional to test whether a specific request was completed, you can use the Nothing keyword.

example.code: Sub AgentControl_RequestComplete (ByVal Request) If Not (MyRequest Is Nothing) Then If Request Is MyRequest Then '-- Do whatever End If End If End Sub

member.name: E:DoubleAgent.Control.Control.RequestStart

summary.para: Signalled when Double Agent begins a queued request.

member.param:
The
object that identifies the queued request.

remarks.para: The event provides a object. Because requests are processed asynchronously, you can use this event to determine when Double Agent begins processing a request (such as a , , or method) and thereby synchronize this with other actions generated by your application. The event is sent only to the client that created the reference to the object, and only if you defined a global variable for the request reference.

example.code:
Dim MyRequest Dim Genie
Sub window_Onload AgentControl.Characters.Load "Genie", "Genie.acs"
Set Genie = AgentControl.Characters("Genie")
' This syntax will generate RequestStart and RequestComplete events. Set MyRequest = Genie.Show(False)
' This syntax will not generate RequestStart and RequestComplete events. Genie.Hide False End Sub
Sub AgentControl_RequestStart(ByVal Request) If Request Is MyRequest Then Status = "Genie is showing" End Sub

remarks.para: The property is 4 (request in progress) for the object.

Because animation objects don't get assigned until Double Agent has queued the request, make sure that the object exists before you attempt to evaluate it. For example, in Visual Basic, if you use a conditional to test whether a specific request was completed, you can use the Nothing keyword.

example.code: Sub AgentControl_RequestStart (ByVal Request) If Not (MyRequest Is Nothing) Then If Request Is MyRequest Then '-- Do whatever End If End If End Sub

summary.para: The Characters collection includes methods and properties for loading, unloading, and accessing s. It can be accessed using the 's property.

item.term: The Characters collection has the following methods:
The Characters collection has the following properties:

member.name: M:DoubleAgent.Control.Characters.Unload

summary.para: Unloads the character data for a loaded character.

member.param: The character's unique identifier specified when the character was loaded.

remarks.para: Use this method when you no longer need a character, to free up memory used to store information about the character. If you access the character again, use the method.
This method does not return a object.

member.name: M:DoubleAgent.Control.Characters.Load

summary.para: Loads a character into the Characters collection.

member.param: A string value that you will use to refer to the character when it's loaded. See the property.

One of the following:
Filespec
The location of a local character definition file (.ACS format)
URL
The HTTP address of the character's definition file (.ACF format)
member.returns:
A
object your application can use to track the status of the Load request. The Load method is asynchronous only when loading a character using the HTTP protocol.

remarks.para: You can load characters from the default location(s) by specifying only a file name. For example, specifying the following would search for Genie.acs using the .

example.code: Control.Character.Load "Genie", "Genie.acs"
example.para: You can also specify an absolute location,
example.code: Control.Character.Load "Genie", "C:\MyCharacters\Genie.acs"
example.para: or specify your own subdirectory by using a relative path.
example.code: Control.Character.Load "Genie", "MyCharacters\Genie.acs"

remarks.para: You can load the default character by omitting the second parameter of the Load method, or passing an empty string. This will load the default character from the .

example.code: Agent.Character.Load "DefChar"

remarks.para: You cannot load the same character (a character having the same ) more than once from a single instance of the control. Similarly, you cannot load the default character and other characters at the same time from a single instance of the control because the default character could be the same as the other character. If you attempt to do this, Double Agent raises an error. However, you can create another instance of the Agent control and load the same character.
Loading a character does not automatically display the character. Use the method first to make the character visible.

details.para: Character data can be loaded from a single structured file (.ACS) with character data and animation data together, or from separate character data (.ACF) and animation (.ACA) files. Use a single structured .ACS file to load a character that's stored on a local disk or network and accessed using a conventional file protocol (such as UNC pathnames). Use separate .ACF and .ACA files when you want to load the animation files individually from a remote site where they're accessed using the HTTP protocol. The Load method does not support downloading .ACS files from an HTTP site.

For .ACS files, using the Load method provides access to a character's animations. For .ACF files, you should also use the method to load animation data. Using is optional, but it will prevent unexpected delays when playing animations.

example.code: Sub Form_Load On Error GoTo ErrorHandler AgentControl.Characters.Load "MyChar", "Genie.acs" ' Successful load . . . Exit Sub ErrorHandler: ' Unsuccessful load . . . Resume Next End Sub

details.para: You can also handle the error by setting to False, declaring an object, and assigning the Load request to it. Then follow the Load call with a statement that checks the status of the object.

example.code:
Dim LoadRequest as Object
Sub Form_Load AgentControl.RaiseRequestErrors = False Set LoadRequest = AgentControl.Characters.Load ("MyChar", "c:\some directory\some character.acs") If LoadRequest.Status Not 0 Then ' Unsuccessful load . . . Exit Sub Else ' Successful load . . . End Sub

details.para: If you load a character using the HTTP protocol, you can also check for a Load failure by assigning a object to the Load method. However, because this method of loading a character is handled asynchronously, check its status in the event. This technique will not work when loading a character using the UNC protocol because the Load method is processed synchronously.

member.name: M:DoubleAgent.Control.Characters.Character

summary.para: Returns a object in the collection.

member.param: The character's unique identifier specified when the character was loaded.
member.returns:
A loaded
object.

remarks.para: You can use this method to access a object's methods and properties.
remarks.note: This method may be required for some programming languages that don't support collections. For languages that do support collections, you can use the language's collection indexing syntax.

summary.para: The Character object provides the methods and properties your application will use to access the bulk of Double Agent's features.

item.term: The Character object has the following methods:
The Character object has the following properties:
item.description:
, , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , ,
The , , , and properties refer to the position and size of the Character, not the location of the Double Agent control.

remarks.para: Because the server loads an HTTP character asynchronously, ensure that the character has been loaded before querying its properties, for example, using the event. Otherwise, the properties may return incorrect values.

item.term: To use a method or property, reference the character in the collection. In VBScript and Visual Basic, you do this by specifying the unique identifier you assigned when you loaded the character:

description.code:
Sub FormLoad 'Load the genie character into the Characters collection AgentControl.Characters.Load "Genie", "Genie.acs"
'Display the character AgentControl.Characters("Genie").Show AgentControl.Characters("Genie").Play "Greet" AgentControl.Characters("Genie").Speak "Hello." End Sub

item.term: To simplify the syntax of your code, you can define an object variable and set it to reference a character object in the collection. Then you can use your variable to reference methods or properties of the character. The following example demonstrates how you can do this using the Visual Basic Set statement:

description.code:
'Define a global object variable Dim Genie as Object
Sub FormLoad 'Load the genie character into the Characters collection AgentControl.Characters.Load "Genie", "Genie.acs"
'Create a reference to the character Set Genie = AgentControl.Characters("Genie")
'Display the character Genie.Show
'Make the character say Hello Genie.Speak "Hello." End Sub

item.term: In Visual Basic, you can also create your reference by declaring your variable as a object:

description.code:
Dim Genie as DaControl.DaCtlCharacter
Sub FormLoad 'Load the genie character into the Characters collection AgentControl.Characters.Load "Genie", "Genie.acs"
'Create a reference to the character Set Genie = AgentControl.Characters("Genie")
'Display the character Genie.Show End Sub
description.para: Declaring an object of type DaCtlCharacter enables early binding on the object, which allows immediate syntax checking and results in better performance.

item.term: In VBScript, you cannot declare a reference as a particular type. However, you can simply declare the variable reference:

description.code:
<SCRIPT LANGUAGE = "VBScript"> <!-- Dim Genie
Sub window_OnLoad 'Load the character AgentCtl.Characters.Load "Genie", "http://agent.microsoft.com/characters/v2/genie/genie.acf"
'Create an object reference to the character in the collection set Genie= AgentCtl.Characters ("Genie")
'Prepare the Showing state animation Genie.Prepare "state", "Showing"
'Display the character Genie.Show End Sub --> </SCRIPT>

item.term: Some programming languages do not support collections. However, you can access a object's methods with the method:
In addition, you can create a reference to the Character object to make your script code easier to follow:

description.code:
<SCRIPT LANGUAGE="JScript" FOR="window" EVENT="onLoad()">
<!--
//Load the character's data
AgentControl.Characters.Load ("Genie", "http://agent.microsoft.com/characters/v2/genie/genie.acf");

//Create a reference to this object
Genie = AgentControl.Characters.Character("Genie");

//Prepare the Showing state animation
Genie.Prepare("state", "Showing");

//Display the character
Genie.Show();
-->
</SCRIPT>

member.name: M:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.Activate

summary.para: Sets the active client or character.

member.param:
You can specify one of the following values for this parameter:
0 Not the active client
1 The active client
2 The input-active character (default)
member.returns: True if the method succeeded.

details.para: When multiple characters are visible, only one of the characters receives speech input at a time. Similarly, when multiple client applications share the same character, only one of the clients receives mouse input (for example, or events). The character set to receive mouse and speech input is the input-active character and the client that receives the input is the active client of that character. (The input-active character's window also appears at the top of the character window's z-order.) Typically, the user determines the input-active character by explicitly selecting the character. However, input activation also changes when a character is shown or hidden (the character becomes or is no longer input-active, respectively.)

You can also use this method to explicitly manage when your client receives input directed to the character such as when your application itself becomes active. For example, setting State to 2 makes the character input-active and your client receives all mouse and speech input events generated from user interaction with the character. Therefore, it also makes your client the input-active client of the character.

However, you can also set yourself to be the active client for a character without making the character input-active, by setting State to 1. This enables your client to receive input directed to that character when the character does become input-active. Similarly, you can set your client to not be the active client (not to receive input) when the character becomes input-active, by setting State to 0.

If you call this method as a function, it returns a boolean value that indicates whether the method succeeded. Attempting to call this method with the State parameter set to 2 when the specified character is hidden will fail. Similarly, if you set State to 0 and your application is the only client, this call fails because a character must always have a input-active client.
details.code:
Dim Genie as Object
Sub FormLoad() AgentControl.Characters.Load "Genie", "Genie.acs"
Set Genie = AgentControl.Characters ("Genie")
If (Genie.Activate = True) Then ' I'm active Else ' I must be hidden or something End If End Sub

remarks.para: Avoid calling this method directly after a method. automatically sets the input-active client. When the character is shown, the Activate call may fail if it gets processed before the method completes.
remarks.note: Calling this method with State set to 1 does not typically generate an event unless there are no other characters loaded or your application is already input-active.

member.name: M:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.GestureAt

summary.para: Plays a character's gesturing animation towards the specified location.

member.param: A numeric value that indicates the horizontal screen coordinate, in pixels, to which the character will gesture.
A numeric value that indicates the vertical screen coordinate, in pixels, to which the character will gesture.
member.returns:
A
object your application can used to track the method's status.

remarks.para: Double Agent automatically plays the appropriate animation to gesture toward the specified location. The coordinates are always relative to the upper left corner of the screen.

summary.para: deprecated

remarks.para: This method has been replaced by the method, but is still supported for backward compatibility.

member.name: M:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.Hide

summary.para: Hides a character.

member.param: A boolean value that indicates whether to skip the character's Hiding state animation.
member.returns:
A
object your application can used to track the method's status.

remarks.para: Double Agent queues the actions of the Hide method in the character's queue, so you can use it to hide the character after a sequence of other animations. You can play the action immediately by using the or method before calling this method.
remarks.note: Hiding a character can trigger the event of another client.
Hidden characters cannot access the screen or the audio channel. Double Agent will pass a failure status in the event if you attempt to animate a hidden character.

member.name: M:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.Interrupt

summary.para: Interrupts an animation for another character.

member.param: The object for the animation call you want to interrupt.
member.returns:
A
object your application can used to track the method's status.

remarks.para: You can use this to synchronize animation between characters. For example, if another character is in a looping animation, this method will stop the loop and move to the next animation in the character's queue.

details.para: To specify the request parameter, create a variable for the animation request you want to interrupt:
details.code:
Dim GenieRequest as Object Dim RobbyRequest as Object Dim Genie as Object Dim Robby as Object
Sub FormLoad() MyAgentControl.Characters.Load "Genie", "Genie.acs" MyAgentControl.Characters.Load "Robby", "Robby.acs"
Set Genie = MyAgentControl.Characters ("Genie") Set Robby = MyAgentControl.Characters ("Robby")
Genie.Show Genie.Speak "Just a moment" Set GenieRequest = Genie.Play ("Processing")
Robby.Show Robby.Play "confused" Robby.Speak "Hey, Genie. What are you doing?" Robby.Interrupt GenieRequest
Genie.Speak "I was just checking on something." End Sub
details.para: You can only use the Interrupt method to interrupt another character. To stop an animation for a single character, use the method.
details.note: The Interrupt method does not flush the character's queue; it halts the specified animation and moves on to the next animation in the character's queue. To halt and flush a character's queue, use that character's method.
You cannot interrupt a character animation that you didn't start (that was started by another client).

member.name: M:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.Listen

summary.para: Turns on Listening mode (speech recognition) for a timed period.

member.param: A boolean value that determines whether to turn Listening mode on or off.
member.returns: True if Listening mode was started.

remarks.para: Setting the Listen parameter to True enables Listening mode (turns on speech recognition) for a fixed period of time (10 seconds). While you cannot set the value of the time-out, you can turn off Listening mode before the time-out expires.

If you (or another client) successfully set Listening mode on and you attempt to set this property to True before the time-out expires, the method succeeds and resets the time-out. However, if the Listening mode is on because the user is pressing the Listening key, the method succeeds, but the time-out is ignored and Listening mode ends based on the user's interaction with the Listening key.

This method succeeds only when called by the input-active client and only if speech services are available. To detect the success of this method, call it as a function and it will return a boolean value indicating whether the method succeeded.

example.code: If Genie.Listen(True) Then ' The method succeeded Else ' The method failed End If

details.para: The method also fails if the user is pressing the Listening key and you attempt to set Listen to False. However, if the user has released the Listening key and Listening mode has not timed out, it will succeed.

Listen also fails if there is no compatible speech engine available that matches the character's setting, the user has disabled speech input using the Advanced Character Options window, or the audio device is busy.
When you successfully set this method to True, the Double Agent triggers the event. Double Agent sends when the Listening mode time-out completes or when you set Listen to False.

This method does not automatically call the method and play a Listening state animation as Double Agent does when the Listening key is pressed. This allows you to determine whether to interrupt the current animation for the event by calling and playing your own appropriate animation. However, the Double Agent does call and plays a Hearing state animation when a user utterance is detected.

member.name: M:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.MoveTo

summary.para: Moves a character to the specified location.

member.param: The horizontal location, in pixels, relative to the left side of the screen.
The vertical location, in pixels, relative to the top of the screen.
An optional numeric value specifying how quickly the character's image moves, in milliseconds. The default value is 1000. Specifying zero moves the image without playing an animation.
member.returns:
A
object your application can used to track the method's status.

remarks.para: The location of a character is based on the upper left corner of its image. Double Agent automatically plays the appropriate animation assigned to the Moving states.
remarks.note: If you call MoveTo with a non-zero Speed before the character is shown, it will return a failure status if you assigned a object, because the non-zero value indicates that you're attempting to play an animation when the character isn't visible.
The Speed parameter's actual effect may vary based on the computer's processor speed and the priority of other tasks running on the system.

member.name: M:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.Play

summary.para: Plays the specified animation for a character.

member.param: A string value that specifies the name of an animation sequence.
member.returns:
A
object your application can used to track the method's status.

remarks.para: An animation's name is defined when the character is authored. Before playing the specified animation, Double Agent attempts to play the Return animation for the previous animation, if one has been assigned.
The Play method does not make the character visible. If the character is not visible, Double Agent plays the animation invisibly, and sets the property of the object.

When accessing a character's animations using a conventional file protocol, you can simply use the Play method specifying the name of the animation. However, if you're using the HTTP protocol to access character animation data, use the method to load the animation before calling the Play method.

member.name: M:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.Prepare

summary.para: Retrieves specified animation data for the a remote character.

member.param:
A string value that indicates the animation data type to load.
"Animation" A character's animation data
"State" A character's state data
"WaveFile" A character's audio (for spoken output) file

A string that indicates the name of the animation resource.
For animations, the name is one of those defined for the character when it was authored.
For states, the following values can be used:
"Gesturing"
To retrieve all Gesturing state animations.
"GesturingDown"
To retrieve the GesturingDown animation.
"GesturingLeft"
To retrieve the GesturingLeft animation.
"GesturingRight"
To retrieve the GesturingRight animation.
"GesturingUp"
To retrieve the GesturingUp animation.
"Hiding"
To retrieve the Hiding state animation.
"Hearing"
To retrieve the Hearing state animation.
"Idling"
To retrieve all Idling state animations.
"IdlingLevel1"
To retrieve all IdlingLevel1 animations.
"IdlingLevel2"
To retrieve all IdlingLevel2 animations.
"IdlingLevel3"
To retrieve all IdlingLevel3 animations.
"Listening"
To retrieve the Listening state animation.
"Moving"
To retrieve all Moving state animations.
"MovingDown"
To retrieve the MovingDown animation.
"MovingLeft"
To retrieve the MovingLeft animation.
"MovingRight"
To retrieve the MovingRight animation.
"MovingUp"
To retrieve the MovingUp animation.
"Showing"
To retrieve the Showing state animation.
"Speaking"
To retrieve the Speaking state animation.
For audio files, specify the location of the .WAV file. If an incomplete path is specified, it's interpreted as being relative to the location used in the method.
You can specify multiple animations and states by separating them with commas. However, you cannot mix types in the same Prepare call.
A boolean value specifying whether the Double Agent queues the Prepare, or starts it immediately.
member.returns:
A
object your application can used to track the method's status.

remarks.para: If you load a character using the HTTP protocol (an .ACF file), you should use the Prepare method to retrieve animation data before you play the animation. You do not use this method if you loaded the character using the UNC protocol (an .ACS file).

Using the Prepare method is not mandatory. If Double Agent requires an animation from an .ACS file, it will load the file automatically (from the same location the .ACF file was loaded). However, this may cause unexpected delays when using the HTTP protocol.

You can declare an object reference and set it to the method's object return value. If the associated animation fails to load, Double Agent sets the object's property to "failed" with an appropriate error number. You can use the event to check the status and determine what action to take.

Animation or sound data retrieved with the Prepare method is cached locally. Subsequent calls will check the cache, and if the animation data is already there, the control loads the data directly from the cache. Once loaded, the animation or sound data can be played with the or methods.

member.name: M:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.Show

summary.para: Makes the specified character visible and optionally plays its associated Showing animation.

member.param: A boolean value specifying whether or not the Showing state animation is played.
member.returns:
A
object your application can used to track the method's status.

remarks.para: Avoid setting the Fast parameter to True without first playing an animation; otherwise, the character may be shown with no image. In particular, note that if you call when the character is not visible, it does not play any animation. Therefore, if you call the Show method with Fast set to True, no image will display. Similarly, if you call , then Show with Fast set to True, there will be no visible image.

member.name: M:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.ShowPopupMenu

summary.para: Displays a character's pop-up menu at the specified location.

member.param: The horizontal screen coordinate to display the menu, in pixels.
The vertical screen coordinate to display the menu, in pixels.
member.returns: True if the method succeeded.

remarks.para: If the property is set to True, Double Agent automatically displays the character's pop-up menu when the user right-clicks the character. If you set to False, you can use ShowPopupMenu to display the menu.

The menu remains displayed until the user selects a command or displays another menu. Only one pop-up menu can be displayed at a time; therefore, calls to this method will cancel (remove) the former menu.

example.code: If Genie.ShowPopupMenu (10,10) = True Then ' The menu was displayed Else ' The menu was not displayed End If

member.name: M:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.Speak

summary.para: Speaks the specified text or sound file for a character.

member.param: A string value that specifies what the character says.

A string value specifying the location of an audio file (.WAV format). The location can be specified as a file (including a UNC path specification) or URL (when character animation data is also being retrieved via HTTP protocol).
member.returns:
A
object your application can used to track the method's status.

remarks.para: At least one of the Text and Url parameters must be supplied. To use this method with a character configured to speak only in its word balloon or using a text-to-speech (TTS) engine, simply provide the Text parameter. Include a space between words to define appropriate word breaks in the word balloon, even for languages that do not traditionally include spaces.
You can also include vertical bar characters (|) in the Text parameter to designate alternative strings, so that Double Agent randomly chooses a different string each time it processes the method.

details.para: Support for TTS output is defined when the character is authored. To generate TTS output, a compatible TTS engine must already be installed before calling this method. For further information, see Accessing Speech Services.
You can vary parameters of the speech output with special tags that you include in the Text parameter. For more information, see Microsoft Agent Speech Output Tags.
details.example:
You can also include bookmark speech tags in your Speak text to synchronize your code:
Dim SpeakRequest as Object ... Set SpeakRequest = Genie.Speak ("And here \mrk=100\it is.") ... Sub AgentControl_Bookmark (ByVal BookmarkID As Long) If BookmarkID = 100 Then ' Display the message box Msgbox "Tada!" End If End Sub For more information on the bookmark speech tag, see Speech Output Tags.
details.para: Agent's automatic word breaking in the word balloon breaks words using white-space characters (for example, Space or Tab). However, if it cannot, it may break a word to fit the balloon. In languages like Japanese, Chinese, and Thai, where spaces are not used to break words, insert a Unicode zero-width space character (0x200B) between characters to define logical word breaks.

If you use recorded sound file (.WAV format only) output for the character, specify the file's location in the Url parameter. This file specification can include a local (absolute or relative) or universal naming convention (UNC) path. The filename cannot include any characters not included in the US code page 1252. However, if you are using the HTTP protocol to access the character data, use the method to load the sound file before calling the Speak method.
When using recorded sound file output, you can still use the Text parameter to specify the words that appear in the character's word balloon.
If you call Speak and the audio channel is busy, the character's audio output will not be heard, but the text will display in the word balloon.

The Speak method uses the last action played to determine which speaking animation to play. For example, if you preceded the Speak command with Play "GestureRight", Double Agent will play GestureRight and then the GestureRight speaking animation. If the last animation played has no speaking animation, Double Agent plays the animation assigned to the character's Speaking state.
details.note: To track the method's status, you can declare an object reference and set it to the method's object return value.
The word balloon's property must also be True for text to display.
Set the character's before using the Speak method to ensure appropriate text display within the word balloon.

member.name: M:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.Stop

summary.para: Stops an animation for a character.

member.param:
A
object specifying a particular animation call, or a null reference to stop all animations.

remarks.para: To specify the request parameter, you must create a variable and assign the animation request you want to stop. If you don't set the Request parameter, Double Agent stops all animations for the character, including queued calls, and clears its animation queue (unless the character is currently playing its Hiding or Showing animation). This method does not stop non-queued calls.

example.para: To stop a specific animation or call, declare an object variable and assign your animation request to that variable:
example.code:
Dim MyRequest Dim Genie
AgentControl.Characters.Load "Genie", "Genie.acs"
Set Genie = AgentControl.Characters ("Genie") Genie.Show
'This animation will never play Set MyRequest = Genie.Play ("Greet")
Genie.Stop MyRequest

remarks.para: This method is performed immediately and does not generate a object.

member.name: M:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.StopAll

summary.para: Stops all animation requests or specified types of requests for a character.

member.param:
You can omit this parameter you or use any of the following values.
"Get"
To stop all queued Get requests.
"NonQueuedGet"
To stop all non-queued Get requests (Get method with Queue parameter set to False).
"Move"
To stop all queued MoveTo requests.
"Play"
To stop all queued Play requests.
"Speak"
To stop all queued Speak requests.
You can also specify multiple types by separating them with commas.

remarks.para: If you don't set the Type parameter, Double Agent stops all animations for the character, including queued and non-queued requests, and clears its animation queue. It also stops playing a character's Hiding or Showing animation.
This method is performed immediately and does not generate a object.

member.name: M:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.Think

summary.para: Displays the specified text in a character's "thought" balloon.

member.param: A string value that specifies the character's thought output.
member.returns:
A
object your application can used to track the method's status.

remarks.para: Like the method, the Think method is a queued request that displays text in a word balloon, except that the Think word balloon differs visually. In addition, the balloon supports only the Bookmark speech control tag (\Mrk) and ignores any other speech control tags. Unlike , the Think method does not change the character's animation state.
The object's properties affect the output of both the and Think methods. For example, the object's property must be True for text to display.

Agent's automatic word breaking in the word balloon breaks words using white-space characters (for example, SPACE or TAB). However, if it cannot, it may break a word to fit the balloon. In languages like Japanese, Chinese, and Thai where spaces are not used to break words, insert a Unicode zero-width space character (0x200B) between characters to define logical word breaks.
remarks.note: To track the method's status, you can declare an object reference and set it to the method's object return value.
Set the character's before using the Think method to ensure appropriate text display within the word balloon.

member.name: M:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.Wait

summary.para: Causes the animation queue for the specified character to wait until the specified animation request completes.

member.param:
A
object specifying the animation to wait for.
member.returns:
A
object your application can used to track the method's status.

remarks.para: Use this method only when you are using multiple (simultaneous) characters and are trying to sequence the interaction of characters. (For a single character, each animation request is played sequentially--after the previous request completes.)
If you have two characters and you want one character's animation request to wait until the other character's animation completes, use the Wait method with the other character's animation object.

example.para: To specify the request parameter, create a variable for animation request you want to wait for:
example.code:
Dim GenieRequest Dim RobbyRequest Dim Genie Dim Robby
Sub window_Onload AgentControl.Characters.Load "Genie", "Genie.acs" AgentControl.Characters.Load "Robby", "Robby.acs"
Set Genie = AgentControl.Characters("Genie") Set Robby = AgentControl.Characters("Robby")
Genie.MoveTo 100,100 Genie.Show
Robby.MoveTo 250,100 Robby.Show
Genie.Play "Announce" Set GenieRequest = Genie.Speak ("Why did the chicken cross the road?")
Robby.Wait GenieRequest Robby.Play "Confused" Set RobbyRequest = Robby.Speak ("I don't know. Why did the chicken cross the road?")
Genie.Wait RobbyRequest Genie.Play "Pleased" Set GenieRequest = Genie.Speak ("To get to the other side.")
Robby.Wait GenieRequest Robby.Play "Sad" Robby.Speak "I never should have asked." End Sub

example.para: You can also streamline your code by just calling Wait directly, using a specific animation request.
example.code: Robby.Wait Genie.Play "GestureRight"
example.para: This avoids having to explicitly declare a object.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.Active

summary.para: Returns whether your application is the active client of the character and whether the character is input-active.

member.param:
A numeric value specifying the state of your client application.
0 Not the active client.
1 The active client.
2 The input-active client (the topmost character).

remarks.para: When multiple client applications share the same character, the active client of the character receives mouse input (for example, Double Agent control Click or Drag events). Similarly, when multiple characters are displayed, the active client of the topmost character (also known as the input-active client) receives Command events.
You can use the method to set whether your application is the active client of the character or to make your application the input-active client (which also makes the character topmost).

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.AutoPopupMenu

summary.para: Returns or sets whether right-clicking the character or its taskbar icon automatically displays the character's pop-up menu.

member.param: A boolean value specifying whether Double Agent automatically displays the character's pop-up menu on right-click.

remarks.para: By setting this property to False, you can create your own menu-handling behavior. To display the menu after setting this property to False, use the method.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.Description

summary.para: Returns or sets a string that specifies the description for the specified character.

member.param: A string value corresponding to the character's description (in the current language setting).

remarks.para: A character's Description may depend on the character's setting. A character's description in one language may be different or use different characters than in another. The character's default Description for a specific language is defined when the character is compiled with the Microsoft Agent Character Editor.
remarks.note: The Description property setting is optional and may not be supplied for all characters.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.ExtraData

summary.para: Returns a string that specifies additional data stored as part of the character.

member.param: A string that contains any additional data stored as part of the character.

remarks.para: The default value for the ExtraData property for a character is defined when the character is compiled with the Microsoft Agent Character Editor. It cannot be changed or specified at run time.
remarks.note: The ExtraData property setting is optional and may not be supplied for all characters.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.GUID

summary.para: Returns the unique identifier for the character.

member.param: The unique identifier for the character.

remarks.para: This property returns a string representing the internal identifier that Double Agent uses to uniquely identify the character. A character identifier is set when it is compiled with the Microsoft Agent Character Editor. The property is read-only.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.Height

summary.para: Returns or sets the height of the specified character's image.

member.param: A numeric value that specifies the character's image height.

remarks.para: The Height property is always expressed in pixels. This property's setting applies to all clients of the character.

Even though the character appears in an irregularly shaped region window, the height of the character is based on the external dimensions of the rectangular animation frame used when the character was compiled with the Microsoft Agent Character Editor.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.IdleEnabled

summary.para: Returns or sets whether the character will show its Idling animations when it's not busy.

member.param: A boolean value specifying whether Double Agent manages idle mode.

remarks.para: Double Agent automatically sets a time-out after the last animation played for a character. When this timer's interval is complete, Double Agent begins the Idling state for a character, playing its associated Idling animations at regular intervals. If you want to disable Double Agent from automatically playing the Idling state animations, set the property to False and play an animation or call the method. Setting this value does not affect the current animation state of the character.

summary.para: deprecated

remarks.para: This property has been replaced by the property, but is still supported for backward compatibility.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.LanguageID

summary.para: Returns or sets the language identifier for the character.

member.param: A numeric value specifying the language ID for the character. The language ID (LANGID) for a character is a 16-bit value defined by Windows, consisting of a primary language ID and a secondary language ID.

remarks.para: If you do not set the LanguageID for the character, its language will be the current system language, if the corresponding Agent language DLL is installed. Otherwise, the character's language will be English (US).

This property also determines the language for word balloon text, the commands in the character's pop-up menu, and the speech recognition engine. It also determines the default language for text-to-speech output.

details.para: If you try to set the LanguageID for a character and the Agent language DLL for that language is not installed or a display font for the language is not available, Agent raises an error and LanguageID remains at its last setting.

Setting this property does not raise an error if there are no matching speech engines for the language. To determine if there is a compatible speech engine available for the LanguageID, check or . If you do not set LanguageID, it will be set to the user default language.
details.note: If you set LanguageID to a language that supports bidirectional text (such as Arabic or Hebrew), but the system running your application does not have bidirectional support installed, text in the word balloon may appear in logical rather than display order.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.Left

summary.para: Returns or sets the left edge of the specified character's image.

member.param: A numeric value that specifies the left edge of the character's image.

remarks.para: The Left property is always expressed in pixels, relative to screen origin (upper left). This property's setting applies to all clients of the character.

Even though the character appears in an irregularly shaped region window, the location of the character is based on the external dimensions of the rectangular animation frame used when the character was compiled with the Microsoft Agent Character Editor.

summary.para: Returns a numeric value that specifies what caused the character's last move.

item.description: The character has not been moved
The user moved the character
Your application moved the character
Another client application moved the character
The Agent server moved the character to keep it onscreen after a screen resolution change

remarks.para: You can use this property to determine what caused the character to move, when more than one application is sharing (has loaded) the same character. These values are the same as those returned by the event.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.Name

summary.para: Returns or sets the specified character's displayed name.

member.param: A string value corresponding to the character's name (in the current language setting).

remarks.para: A character's Name may depend on the character's setting. A character's name in one language may be different or use different characters than in another. The character's default Name for a specific language is defined when the character is compiled with the Microsoft Agent Character Editor.

Avoid renaming a character, especially when using it in a scenario where other client applications may use the same character. Also, Double Agent uses the character's Name to automatically create commands for hiding and showing the character.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.OriginalHeight

summary.para: Returns a numeric value that specifies the character's original height.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.SoundEffectsOn

summary.para: Returns or sets whether sound effects are enabled for your character.

member.param: A boolean value specifying whether sound effects are enabled.

remarks.para: This property determines whether the sound effects included as a part of a character's animations will play when an animation plays. This property's setting applies to all clients of the character.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.SRModeID

summary.para: Returns or sets the speech recognition engine the character uses.

member.param: A string value that identifies a speech recognition engine.

remarks.para: This property determines the speech recognition engine used by the character for speech input. The SRModeID for a speech recognition engine is a formatted string defined by the vendor that uniquely identifies the engine.

details.para: If you specify the SRModeID for a speech engine that isn't installed, if the user has disabled speech recognition, or if the language of the specified speech engine doesn't match the character's setting, Double Agent raises an error.

If you query this property and haven't already (successfully) set the speech recognition engine, the server returns the SRModeID of the engine that SAPI returns based on the character's setting. If you haven't set the character's , then Double Agent returns the SRModeID of the engine that SAPI returns based on the user's default language setting. If there is no matching engine, Double Agent returns an empty string ("").
Querying this property does not require that be set to True. However, if you query the property when speech input is disabled, Double Agent returns an empty string.

When speech input is enabled, querying or setting this property will load the associated engine (if it is not already loaded), and start speech services. That is, the Listening key is available, and the Listening Tip is displayable. (The Listening key and Listening Tip are enabled only if they are also enabled in the .) However, if you query the property when speech is disabled, Double Agent does not start speech services.

summary.para: Returns whether speech input can be started for the character.

item.description: Conditions support speech input.

There is no audio input device available on this system. (Note that this does not detect whether or not a microphone is installed; it can only detect whether the user has a properly installed input-enabled sound card with a working driver.)
Another client is the active client of this character, or the current character is not topmost
The audio input or output channel is currently busy, an application is using audio

An unspecified error occurred in the process of initializing the speech recognition subsystem. This includes the possibility that there is no speech engine available matching the character's language setting
The user has disabled speech input in the Advanced Character Options
An error occurred in checking the audio status, but the cause of the error was not returned by the system

remarks.para: This property checks for the conditions necessary to support speech input, including the status of the audio device. You can check this property before you call the method to better ensure its success.

details.para: When speech input is enabled in the , querying this property will load the associated engine, if it is not already loaded, and start speech services. That is, the Listening key is available, and the Listening Tip is automatically displayable. (The Listening key and Listening Tip are only enabled if they are also enabled in the .) However, if you query the property when speech is disabled, Double Agent does not start speech services.
This property only applies to your client application's use of the character; the setting does not affect other clients of the character or other characters of your client application.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.Top

summary.para: Returns or sets the top edge of the specified character's image.

member.param: A numeric value that specifies the character's top edge.

remarks.para: The Top property is always expressed in pixels, relative to screen origin (upper left). This property's setting applies to all clients of the character.

Even though the character appears in an irregularly shaped region window, the location of the character is based on the external dimensions of the rectangular animation frame used when the character was compiled with the Microsoft Agent Character Editor.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.TTSModeID

summary.para: Returns or sets the text-to-speech engine used for the character.

member.param: A string value that uniquely identifies a text-to-speech engine and synthesis mode.

remarks.para: This property determines the TTS (text-to-speech) engine for a character's spoken output. The TTSModeID for a TTS engine is a formatted string defined by the vendor that uniquely identifies the engine and it's synthesis mode.

details.para: Setting this property overrides Double Agent's attempt to load an engine based on the character's compiled TTS setting and the character's current setting. However, if you specify a mode ID for an engine that isn't installed or if the user has disabled speech output in the , Double Agent raises an error.

If you do not (or have not successfully) set the character's TTSModeID, Double Agent checks to see if the character's compiled TTS mode setting matches the character's setting, and if the associated TTS engine is installed. If so, the character's TTSModeID is initialized accordingly. If not, Double Agent looks for a compatible SAPI speech engine that matches the character's and gender. If you have not set the character's , the current user language is used. If no matching engine can be found, this property returns an empty string. Similarly, if you query this property when the user has disabled speech output in the , the value will be an empty string.

Querying or setting this property will load the associated engine (if it is not already loaded). However, if the engine specified in the character's compiled TTS setting is installed and matches the character's setting, the engine will be loaded when the character loads.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.Version

summary.para: Returns the character's version.

member.param: A string that identifies the Microsoft Agent version for which the character was built.

remarks.para: The Version property returns a string that corresponds to the version of the standard animation set definition for which the character was compiled. The character's version number is automatically set when you build it with the Microsoft Agent Character Editor.

summary.para: Returns a numeric value that specifies what caused the character's visible state to change.

item.description: The character has not been shown.
User hid the character using the command on the character's taskbar icon pop-up menu or using speech input.
The user showed the character
Your application hid the character
Your application showed the character
Another client application hid the character
Another client application showed the character
The user hid the character using the command on the character's pop-up menu

remarks.para: You can use this property to determine what caused the character to change visibility when more than one application is sharing (has loaded) the same character. These values are the same as those returned by the and events.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.Visible

summary.para: Returns a boolean indicating whether or not the character is visible.

member.param: True if the character is displayed, false if it's hidden

remarks.para: This property indicates whether the character's animationa are being displayed. It does not necessarily mean that there is an image on the screen. For example, this property returns True even when the character is positioned off the visible display area or when the current character animation contains no images. This property's setting applies to all clients of the character.
This property is read-only. To make a character visible or hidden, use the or methods.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Commands.GlobalVoiceCommandsEnabled

summary.para: Returns or sets whether pre-defined commands appear in the window.

member.param: A boolean value that indicates if global voice commands are enabled.

remarks.para: Double Agent automatically adds voice commands (grammar) for opening and closing the window and for showing and hiding the character. If you set GlobalVoiceCommandsEnabled to False, Agent disables any voice parameters for these voide commands as well as the voice commands for the of other clients' objects. This allows you to eliminate these from your client's current active grammar. However, because this potentially blocks voice access to other clients, reset this property to True after processing the user's voice input.
Disabling the property does not affect the character's pop-up menu. The global commands added by Double Agent will still appear; you cannot remove them from the pop-up menu.

summary.para: A Command object is an item in a collection. Double Agent provides the user access to your Command objects when your client application becomes input-active.

item.term: The Command object has the following properties:

remarks.para: A command may appear in either the character's pop-up menu and the window, or in both. To appear in the pop-up menu it must have a and have the property set to True. In addition, its collection's property must also be set to True. To appear in the window, a Command must have its and properties set.

When Double Agent receives input for one of your commands, it sends a event, and passes back the name of the Command as an attribute of the object. You can then use conditional statements to match and process the Command.

Note that a character's pop-up menu entries do not change while the menu is displayed. If you add or remove commands or change their properties while the character's pop-up menu is displayed, the menu reflects those changes whenever the user next shows it. However, the window dynamically reflects any changes you make.

item.term: To access the properties of a Command object, you reference it in its collection using its property. In VBScript and Visual Basic you can use the property directly:
For programming languages that don't support collections, use the method:
You can also use a Command object by creating a reference to it. In Visual Basic, declare an object variable and use the Set statement to create the reference:

description.code: Dim Command1 as Object ... Set Command1 = Agent.Characters("MyCharacterID").Commands("SampleCommand") ... Command1.Enabled = True

item.term: You can also declare the object as type DaCtlCommand and create the reference. This convention enables early syntax checking and binding, which results in better performance:

description.code: Dim Command1 as DaControl.DaCtlCommand ... Set Command1 = Agent.Characters("MyCharacterID").Commands("SampleCommand") ... Command1.Enabled = True

item.term: In VBScript, you can't declare a reference as a particular type, but you can still declare the variable and set it to the Command in the collection:

description.code: Dim Command1 ... Set Command1 = Agent.Characters("MyCharacterID").Commands("SampleCommand") ... Command1.Enabled = True

details.para: The following table summarizes how the properties of a Command affect its presentation:

summary.para: Double Agent supports textual captioning of the method using a cartoon word balloon. The method lets you display text without audio output in a "thought" word balloon.
The Balloon object allows you to customize the appearance and behavior of a character's word balloon. It can be accessed using the 's property.

item.term: The Balloon object has the following properties:

remarks.para: A character's initial word balloon window defaults are defined and compiled in the Microsoft Agent Character Editor. Once running, the balloon's Enabled and Font properties may be overridden by the user. If a user changes the word balloon's properties, they affect all characters. Both the and word balloons use the same property settings for size. You can access the properties for a character's word balloon through the Balloon object, which is a child of the object.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Balloon.Style

summary.para: Returns or sets the character's word balloon output style.

member.param:
An numeric value that represents the balloon's output style. The style value is a bit field with bits defined as follows:
bit 0
bit 1
bit 2
bit 3
bit 4
bits 16-23
bits 24-31

remarks.para: All of the settings included in the Style property can be accessed using specific object properties. The Style property lets you retrieve or set all of these settings at once.

list.item: When the style bit is set to 1, the word balloon appears when the or method is used, unless the user overrides this setting in the window. When set to 0, the word balloon does not appear.

When the style bit is set to 1, the word balloon automatically adjusts the height of the balloon to the current size of the text for the or request. When set to 0, the balloon's height is based on the property. If this style is set and you attempt to set the property, Double Agent raises an error.

When the style bit is set to 1, the word balloon automatically hides when spoken output completes. When set to 0, the balloon remains displayed until the next or call, the character is hidden, or the user clicks or drags the character.

When the style bit is set to 1, the word balloon paces its text output based on the current output rate, for example one word at a time. When output exceeds the size of the balloon, the text is automatically scrolled. When set to 0, all text included in a or request is displayed at once.

The Style property also contains the in the lower byte of the upper word and the in the high byte of the upper word. The value for the must be between 8 and 255, and the must be between 1 and 128. If you provide an invalid value for the Style property, Double Agent will raise an error.

details.para: The defaults for the Style property are set when the character is compiled with the Microsoft Agent Character Editor.
details.note: The Style property can be set even if the user has disabled word balloons in the window.

summary.para: Returns or sets the visiblity of a character's word balloon.

remarks.para: If you follow a or call with a statement that changes this property, it may not affect the balloon's Visible state because the or call gets queued, but the call to set this property does not. Therefore, only set this value when no or calls are in the character's queue.
If you attempt to set this property while the character is speaking, moving, or being dragged, the property setting does not take effect until the preceding operation is completed.

Calling the and methods automatically makes the balloon visible, setting the Visible property to True. If the character's balloon property is enabled, the balloon is automatically hidden after the text output is complete. Clicking or dragging a character that is not currently speaking also automatically hides the balloon even if its setting is disabled.

summary.para: Double Agent processes some methods, such as , , and , asynchronously. This allows your application code to continue while the method is completing. When a client application calls one of these methods, the control queues the request and returns a Request object.

The Request object provides several
you can use to check the status of your request by keeping a reference to the object.

remarks.para: If you create a Request object reference, Double Agent automatically notifies you when an animation request has started or completed through the and events. Because methods that return Request objects are asynchronous and may not complete during the scope of the calling function, declare your reference to the Request object globally.
The following methods can return a Request object: , , , , , , , , , , and .

example.para: In Visual Basic, first declare an object variable:
example.code: Dim MyRequest as Object
example.para: In VBScript, you don't include the variable type in your declaration:
example.code: Dim MyRequest
example.para: And use Visual Basic's Set statement to assign the variable to the return value of the method call:
example.code: Set MyRequest = control.Characters("CharacterID").method (parameter[s])
example.para: This adds a reference to the Request object. The Request object will be destroyed when there are no more references to it. Where you declare the Request object and how you use it determines its lifetime. If the object is declared local to a subroutine or function, it will be destroyed when it goes out of scope; that is, when the subroutine or function ends. If the object is declared globally, it will not be destroyed until either the program terminates or a new value (or a value set to "empty") is assigned to the object.

summary.para: The object provides the , and properties you can use to check the status of a request.

member.param: A string value that corresponds to the error Number. If no description is found for an error, Description contains "Application-defined or object-defined error".

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Request.Number

summary.para: Returns the error or cause of the code.

member.param: The error or cause of the Status code. If there is no error, this value is zero.

remarks.para: For the values and meanings of the Number property, see Microsoft Agent Error Codes.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Request.Status

summary.para: You can use the Status property to check the status of your request.

details.code:
Dim MyRequest
Set MyRequest = AgentControl.Characters("Genie").Play ("GetAttention")
If (MyRequest.Status = 2) then 'do something Else If (MyRequest.Status = 0) then 'do something right away End If

member.param:
The current status of the request.
0 Request successfully completed
1 Request failed
2 Request pending (in the queue, but not complete)
3 Request interrupted
4 Request in progress

member.name: T:DoubleAgent.Control.AnimationNames

summary.para: The AnimationNames collection is a special collection that contains the list of animations defined for a character.

member.details:
You can use the collection to enumerate the names of a character's animations. For example, in Visual Basic or VBScript you can access these names using the For Each…Next statements:
For Each Animation in Genie.AnimationNames Genie.Play Animation Next
member.remarks: For .ACF characters, the collection returns all the animations that have been defined for the character, not just the ones that have been retrieved with the method.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.AnimationNames
member.summary: The collection includes properties for accessing its items.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.AnimationNames.Count
member.summary: Returns the count of items in the collection.
member.param: The number of items in the collection

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.AnimationNames.Item
member.summary: Returns an item in the collection.
member.param: The zero-based index of the item to retrieve
An animation name string

summary.para:
Double Agent sends the event when your application is input-active and the user chooses a command from the character's pop-up menu or by spoken input. The event passes a UserInput object whose
identify the number of possible matching commands as well as the name, confidence scoring, and voice text for those matches.

details.para: If voice input triggers this event, Double Agent returns a string that identifies the best match in the parameter, and the second- and third-best matches in and . An empty string indicates that the input did not match any command your application defined. If, for example, the command was matched to the pre-defined Hide command, an empty string would be returned in the parameter, but you would still receive the text heard in the parameter.

You may get the same command name returned in more than one entry. , , and parameters return the relative scores, in the range of -100 to 100, that are returned by the speech recognition engine for each respective match. , , and parameters return the voice text that the speech recognition engine matched for each alternative. If returns zero, Double Agent detected spoken input, but determined that there was no matching command.

If voice input was not the source for the command, for example, if the user selected the command from the character's pop-up menu, Double Agent returns the name of the selected command in the property. It also returns the value of the parameter as 100, and the value of the parameters as an empty string (""). and also return empty strings. and return zero, and and return empty strings. returns 1.

remarks.para: Not all speech recognition engines may return all the values for all the properties of this object. Check with your engine vendor to determine whether the engine supports the Microsoft Speech API interface for returning alternatives and confidence scores.

member.param: The name of the third-best matching .

summary.para: The CommandsWindow object provides access to Double Agent's Voice Commands window.

Its
allow you to show and hide the window, and retrieve and update the window's location. It can be accessed using the 's property.

remarks.para: The Voice Commands window is shared among all Double Agent clients. Changes to the window's location and visibility should be made with this in mind.

summary.para: The CommandsWindow object provides access to Double Agent's Voice Commands window.

summary.para: The PropertySheet object provides access to the Advanced Character Options window.

Its
allow you to show and hide the window, and retrieve and update the window's location and current page. It can be accessed using the 's property.

remarks.para: The Advanced Character Options window is shared among all Double Agent clients. Changes to the window's location and visibility should be made with this in mind.
remarks.note: The Advanced Character Options window combines the Microsoft Agent Advanced Character Options and Default Character Options windows.

summary.para: The PropertySheet object provides access to the Advanced Character Options window.

remarks.para: The Advanced Character Options window is shared among all Double Agent clients. Changes to the window's location and visibility should be made with this in mind.

remarks.para: Double Agent remembers and reuses the window location set by the user.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.PropertySheet.Page

summary.para: Returns or sets the page displayed in the Advanced Character Options window.

member.param:
A string value indicating the visible page.
"Output"
Selects the Output page.
"Speech"
Selects the Speech Input page.
"Character"
Selects the Gallery (default character selection) page.
"Copyright"
Selects the Copyright page.

remarks.para: If no speech engine is installed, setting Page to "Speech" has no effect. Also, the window's property must be set to True for the user to see the page.
remarks.note: When the user closes the window, this property is set to the last page shown.
